body.value: The Green Town published by Scribner’s in 1956
nominated for the National Book Award for poetry in 1957
winner of the Melville Kane Poetry Award
anthologies Poet’s Choice co-edited with Paul Engle (1952)
The Short Story (Macmillan, 1956) co-edited with James B. Hall
1955 and 1956 Amy Lowell Traveling Poetry Fellowship
1966 National Council of Arts Grant in Poetry
written in answer to a critic
grotto in the southern coast of Italy
killed in the Philippines in WWII
former infantry officer of the German Army
reading at the Lexington Y in NYC in 1954
beginning of poem “A Seachange for Harold”.
Reads beginning of “A Seachange for Harold”.
Introduces “An Open Letter to Ralph Ellison”.
Ralph Ellison and his wife   Fanny
beach on small Italian fishing town
Reads “An Open Letter to Ralph Ellison”.

book of letters to famous people
Reads “How It, So Help Me, Was”.
Introduces “La Donna a Roma, an Odyssey”.
teacher of art at an American    university
Reads “La Donna a Roma, an Odyssey”.
Reads “Not Quite a Conversation: A Half-Song, part 1: He and Her”.
Reads “Not Quite a Conversation: A Half-Song, part 2: She and Him”
Introduces second part of reading and “Singing in Late Summer”.
Reads “The Jewish Cemetery in Leningrad” by Joseph Brodsky.
probably intended for Poetry from the Russian Underground but was never published
Continues reading “The Jewish Cemetery in Leningrad” by Joseph Bordsky.
Explains “The Jewish Cemetery in Leningrad” translations, introduces first line         “Conditions” by Artyemy Mikhailov.
Reads first line “Conditions” by Artyemy Mikhailov.
Introduces “Now that I Know” by Vladimir Kovshin.
Reads “Now that I Know” by Vladimir Kovshin.

part of the long March from   Russia called Etape
